is a tree-lined town with a very English feel, known as the Town of Trees. It is in the
, and the great Waikato River flows through it. Central Cambridge is on the north side of the river, and the suburb of Leamington is on the south side. The town had a population of 15,000 in 2006.
European settlers established the town of Cambridge in 1864. The town was named after Prince George, Duke of Cambridge, the Commander-in-Chief of the British Army at the time.
Cambridge is on State Highway 1. From
drive 24 km south-east on SH 1. From
you can take SH 1 through Hamilton, or turn off at
and take SH 1B (the Hamilton bypass), which rejoins SH 1 at Cambridge. Pay attention to the direction signs on 1B, as sometimes it seems like you have to turn off a main road onto a side road.
on either side of Cambridge. The bus stop is centrally located, in Lake St, behind the town hall and i-Site centre.
operates M–F and can be booked at +64 7 827 5999. There is one car rental firm,

value: directions=From Victoria St in Cambridge, proceed over the high level bridge, take first exit on roundabout onto Pope Tce, continue onto Cook St. At the roundabout take the 2nd exit onto Shakespeare St. Turn left onto Browning St for 700m. Turn right onto Carlyle St, go 550m, continue on Roto-o-rangi Rd for 12.3km, turn left onto Parklands Rd for 6.7km, turn right onto Monckton Rd go 2.6km. Turn left onto Arapuni Road for 10.5km. Turn left into Tari Rd and continue to end of road. Set your GPS to the address since Google Maps takes you to the wrong side.

hours=Manu Tioriori Visitor Centre & Southern Enclosure daily Oct–Mar 10:00–18:00, Apr–Sep 10:00–16:00. Over the Mountain track & Northern Enclosure are accessible 24/7 but for visitor safety and that of the flora and fauna, not recommended after dark
price=Southern Enclosure $15, 5–16yr $6, senior >65yr/student with ID $10, family of 2 adults and up to 3 children 5–16yr $34 (additional child $6)

content=An area of native New Zealand bush that has been fenced off with 47km of predator proof fence. They are working on clearing all predators from the interior and re-introducing native wildlife to the area including kiwis, kakapo and tuatara. You're free to walk through the main enclosure, but the guided tours around the park are really good.
content=Rides in a 450 HP V8 jet boat on the Waikato River. Thrill rides and more gentle scenic rides, including trips up to the base of the Karapiro Dam.
directions=take Thornton Rd east out of town
